gr.forth.ics.util
Class Partition<E>

java.lang.Object
  gr.forth.ics.util.Partition<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the arbitrary (user-defined) element associated with a partition
public class Partition<E>
extends java.lang.Object

Implementation of disjoint-set data structure, providing merge(merge)/find operations, in order to be able to track whether two elements belong in the same set or not, and to efficiently merge two sets.

The set that contains a particular element e (of type Partition is accessed by e.find(). Note that the returned set is merely an element itself, which is used as a representative of the set. So, if two elements have the same representative, they belong to the same set. Otherwise, they belong to different sets. Note that the elements of a particular set cannot be queried directly. Thus, perhaps confusingly, a Partition represents both a single element and potentially a set of elements, in the particular partition happens to be chosen as the representative of its set.

A partition is initially created as a singleton. It accepts an arbitrary (user-defined) value (of type <E>) that is permanently associated with the created partition, and can be accessed by value(). A created partition is independent from any other created partition. This means that the return value of find() is unique, and method areMerged(Partition, Partition) always returns false when given such a partition as an argument.

A partition p1 may be merged with another partition p2 by p1.merge(p2); (or, equivalently, p2.merge(p1);). From that point on, this invariant is created: p1.find() == p2.find() which remains true regardless of other future merge operations. Similarly, areMerged(p1, p2) will always return true.

All methods throw NullPointerException if given null arguments.

See Also:
Disjoint-set data structure article on Wikipedia

Method Detail

singleton

public static <E> Partition<E> singleton(E value)
Creates a partition of a singleton set, containing only itself. The created partition is permanently associated with the specified value, which can be accessed by value().

Type Parameters:
E - the type of the user-defined value
Parameters:
value - the value to associate with the created partition
Returns:
the created partition

value

public E value()
Returns the value associated with this partition upon creation.

Returns:
the value associated with this partition upon creation

merge

public Partition<?> merge(Partition<?> other)
Merges this partition with another one. This has the following implications:
  • this.find() == other.find() will be true, forever
  • Partition.areMerged(this, other) will return true, forever

Parameters:
other - the partition to merge this partition with
Returns:
a partition representing the merged partitions. It will be either equal to either this.find() or other.find(), i.e. one representative of the partitions which will be elected to represent the union

find

public Partition<?> find()
Returns the unique representative of the set that this element belongs to. The returned instance can be compared with the representative of another element, to check whether the two elements belong to the same set (when the two representatives will be identical)

Returns:
the unique representative of the set that this partition belongs to

areMerged

public static boolean areMerged(Partition<?> partition1,
                                Partition<?> partition2)
Checks whether the two elements have been merged.

Equivalent to partition1.find() == partition2.find().

Parameters:
partition1 - the first element
partition2 - the second element
Returns:
whether the two partitions have been merged
